author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Drag Proms and Comfort Food With Truffles
description: And: Georgina Bloomberg on being the child of a politician.
content: With the New York charity circuit on hiatus, here is how some philanthropists and society figures are spending their time and resources during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: A Great Election, Against All Odds
description: Democracy is hard work. That work paid off.
content: The 2020 election was not simply free of fraud, or whatever cooked-up malfeasance the president is braying about at this hour. It was, from an administrative standpoint, a resounding success. In the face of a raging pandemic and the highest turnout in more than a century, Americans enjoyed one of the most secure, most accurate and most well-run elections ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Allyson Waller
title: The latest virus wave appears to have crested in Europe, but the struggle is far from over.
description: The latest wave of the coronavirus has inundated Europe after a summer in which many of its countries appeared to have brought the pandemic under control more effectively than the Americas did.
content: The latest wave of the coronavirus has inundated Europe after a summer in which many of its countries appeared to have brought the pandemic under control more effectively than the Americas did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo and Katherine Cusumano
title: Cook an Indigenous Meal or Dance with Dua Lipa
description: Spend this holiday week experimenting with turkey bones, painting botanical art or running a virtual race.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas H. Kean and Tim Roemer
title: Our National Security Depends on Joe Biden’s Transition
description: Why President Trump’s stonewalling makes America less safe.
content: The threats our nation faces today are complex and interrelated — cyberattacks that seek to undermine our elections; violent extremism and white nationalism; the proliferation of nuclear weapons and loose nuclear material; extreme weather disasters made worse by climate change; and a public health emergency that has killed over 250,000 Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: What We Learned From Week 11 of the N.F.L. Season
description: Joe Burrow’s rookie season is over after a knee injury. The Titans beat the Ravens in overtime, the Steelers improved to 10-0 and the Colts outlasted the Packers.
content: Backup quarterbacks securing big wins. An overtime thriller in Baltimore. And the end of a ridiculously promising rookie season for Cincinnati’s Joe Burrow. Sunday was a reminder of how unpredictable the N.F.L. can be, as well as how cruel it can be.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 22, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 22, 2020.
content: An article last Sunday about the political correspondent Abby Phillip misstated the year CNN hired her. It was 2017, not 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: Now the U.S. Has Lots of Ventilators, but Too Few Specialists to Operate Them
description: A burst of production solved the dire shortage that defined the first wave of the coronavirus. But the surplus may not be enough to prevent large numbers of deaths.
content: As record numbers of coronavirus cases overwhelm hospitals across the United States, there is something strikingly different from the surge that inundated cities in the spring: No one is clamoring for ventilators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Cándido Camero, Conga Master Who Transformed Jazz, Dies at 99
description: He brought Afro-Cuban influences to American ensembles and dazzled audiences with his virtuosic multiple-drum technique.
content: “When you talk about percussion, particularly the evolution of conga playing, you’re talking about two periods — before Cándido and after Cándido,” the Grammy-nominated percussionist and bandleader Bobby Sanabria said on Friday, having just attended a memorial service for Cándido Camero. “His contributions were literally game changing.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘Man to Man’
description: Wil S. Hylton’s cousin was his hero. Until the day that cousin tried to kill him.
content: For years, Wil S. Hylton had been drawn to his cousin’s strength and violence. He was pulled in by the archetype that he embodied and was envious of the power he seemed to command.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Bruce Swedien, a Shaper of Michael Jackson’s Sound, Dies at 86
description: In more than 60 years as a recording engineer, he worked with a wide range of artists. His most notable collaboration was with Mr. Jackson and the producer Quincy Jones.
content: Bruce Swedien, a Grammy Award-winning recording engineer best known for his collaboration with Michael Jackson and the producer Quincy Jones on the hit albums “Thriller” and “Off the Wall,” died on Nov. 16 in Gainesville, Fla. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Hollywood’s ‘We’re Not in Kansas Anymore’ Moment
description: The announcement that “Wonder Woman 1984” will be released in theaters and on HBO Max on Christmas Day is the clearest sign that streaming is now central to the film industry’s business model.
content: LOS ANGELES — In explaining why WarnerMedia had decided to release the much-anticipated big-budget “Wonder Woman 1984” simultaneously in theaters and on the streaming service HBO Max on Christmas Day, the company’s chief executive, Jason Kilar, invoked the classic Hollywood film “The Wizard of Oz.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: On Running While Black, With More Hope Than Before
description: As Black Lives Matter signs popped up in recent months, our columnist grew less wary of running in predominantly white neighborhoods. But is that optimism premature?
content: SEATTLE — The bloom of the Black Lives Matter signs. That is what my son and I saw as we jogged through our mostly white neighborhood. Everywhere we looked, we could see what felt like change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nic Wirtz and Natalie Kitroeff
title: Protesters in Guatemala Set Fire to Congress Building Over Spending Cuts
description: After two hurricanes displaced thousands of people and wrecked infrastructure, a bill that cut spending on health and education and bolstered lawmakers’ meal stipends touched off a wave of anger in the capital.
content: ANTIGUA, Guatemala — Thousands of protesters took to the streets in Guatemala’s capital on Saturday, setting fire to the nation’s congressional building in a show of anger over a budget bill passed this week that cut funding for health care and education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein and Jesse McKinley
title: N.Y.C. says 3 percent of its coronavirus tests reveal infections. Why does the state disagree?
description: A 3 percent positive rate in coronavirus testing is a critical threshold for New York City. It is the point at which the mayor shut down public schools last week. The governor says that a sustained 3 percent level in the city will result in banning indoor dining, closing gyms and hair salons, and placing a 25-person cap on attendance at houses of worship even as the holidays approach.
content: A 3 percent positive rate in coronavirus testing is a critical threshold for New York City. It is the point at which the mayor shut down public schools last week. The governor says that a sustained 3 percent level in the city will result in banning indoor dining, closing gyms and hair salons, and placing a 25-person cap on attendance at houses of worship even as the holidays approach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Quick Trip to a Store and Back
description: Stanley Newman opens our solving week.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — So, an Australian wind instrument, a system of underwater mountains and a wedding attendant walk into a bar and …
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: Dear Jets: There’s Hope to Be Found in a Winless Season. Take It From Someone Who Knows.
description: For one thing, you are leading the race for the top draft pick. But seriously, even finishing at 0-16 can yield valuable resilience. So says Hue Jackson, who coached the winless 2017 Cleveland Browns.
content: Only two N.F.L. teams in history have gone 0-16 since the regular season expanded to 16 games in 1978: the Detroit Lions in 2008 and the Cleveland Browns in 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Berreby
title: Can We Make Our Robots Less Biased Than We Are?
description: A.I. developers are committing to end the injustices in how their technology is often made and used.
content: On a summer night in Dallas in 2016, a bomb-handling robot made technological history. Police officers had attached roughly a pound of C-4 explosive to it, steered the device up to a wall near an active shooter and detonated the charge. In the explosion, the assailant, Micah Xavier Johnson, became the first person in the United States to be killed by a police robot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israeli Panel to Look Into Submarine Scandal, Riling Netanyahu
description: A decision by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s rival defense minister, Benny Gantz, to hold an inquiry could further destabilize their unity government.
content: JERUSALEM — Israel’s defense minister announced on Sunday the establishment of a governmental commission of inquiry into the multibillion-dollar purchase of submarines and missile boats under Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, an episode often described as the worst corruption scandal in Israel’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Get Me Meacham! Biden Brings Back the Media’s Good Old Days
description: The next president promises to do for old-line newspaper columnists what Donald Trump did for cable. What a time to be George Will!
content: One afternoon in the spring of 2009, Jon Meacham sat in front of the freighted wooden bookshelf in his office and talked to me about a job writing for Newsweek.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and John Koblin
title: Newsmax, Once a Right-Wing Also-Ran, Is Rising, and Trump Approves
description: A once-niche conservative cable network, owned by a longtime friend of the president, lures audiences by refusing to declare an electoral winner.
content: Flanked by aides in the Oval Office on Wednesday, President Trump dialed up a friend in the news media with a message: Keep up the good work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 23, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset, Annie Karni, Michael Levenson and Astead W. Herndon
title: Senator Kelly Loeffler is in isolation after conflicting virus test results.
description: Senator Kelly Loeffler of Georgia, a Republican who is campaigning in a high-stakes runoff election that could determine control of the Senate, is isolating “out of an abundance of caution,” a campaign spokesman said Sunday, after a series of coronavirus tests delivered mixed messages about whether she had contracted the disease. The latest results showed that she had tested negative.
content: Senator Kelly Loeffler of Georgia, a Republican who is campaigning in a high-stakes runoff election that could determine control of the Senate, is isolating “out of an abundance of caution,” a campaign spokesman said Sunday, after a series of coronavirus tests delivered mixed messages about whether she had contracted the disease. The latest results showed that she had tested negative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Guitar Center Files for Bankruptcy
description: The filing by the nation’s largest retailer of musical instruments highlights the growing gap between the strongest and weakest companies in the pandemic.
content: Guitar Center, the country’s largest retailer of musical instruments, filed for bankruptcy protection late Saturday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Alan Rappeport
title: G20 Summit Closes With Little Progress and Big Gaps Between Trump and Allies
description: World leaders committed to some efforts to fight the coronavirus pandemic, but the meeting illustrated the difficulty of carrying out an agenda when the United States is indifferent or hostile to many goals.
content: WASHINGTON — Officials at the Group of 20 summit meeting released a closing statement on Sunday that served as perhaps the Trump administration’s final reminder of the wide gulf between the United States and its allies on handling global threats like the coronavirus pandemic and climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: More Republicans Tiptoe Toward Acknowledging Biden’s Victory
description: Many of the most vocal Republicans denouncing President Trump’s refusal to concede are out of office or retiring, but some others have started to join them on urging the transition to officially begin.
content: WASHINGTON — As President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. prepares to name his first slate of cabinet appointees, more Republicans are starting to push for the transition to officially begin and calling on their conservative colleagues to openly acknowledge his victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas and Noah Weiland
title: F.D.A. Grants Emergency Authorization of Antibody Treatment Given to Trump
description: The treatment, made by the biotech company Regeneron, is a cocktail of two powerful antibodies that have shown promise for people who get it early in the course of the disease.
content: The Food and Drug Administration has granted emergency authorization for the experimental antibody treatment given to President Trump shortly after he was diagnosed with Covid-19, giving doctors another option to treat Covid-19 patients as cases across the country continue to rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas and Noah Weiland
title: The F.D.A. grants emergency authorization of the coronavirus antibody treatment given to Trump.
description: The Food and Drug Administration has granted emergency authorization for the experimental antibody treatment given to President Trump shortly after he tested positive for  the coronavirus, giving doctors another option to treat patients as cases across the country continue to rise.
content: The Food and Drug Administration has granted emergency authorization for the experimental antibody treatment given to President Trump shortly after he tested positive for  the coronavirus, giving doctors another option to treat patients as cases across the country continue to rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Taimoor Shah
title: Where the Pomegranate Harvest Is Life, the Taliban Brought Ruin
description: An incursion that devastated a prized crop shows the loss and uncertainty that many Afghans endure.
content: ARGHANDAB, Afghanistan — Crack a pomegranate in half and its blood-red seed-filled chambers make it look almost like a broken heart. In Arghandab district, which in Afghanistan is almost synonymous with the fruit, a Taliban offensive has cut the heart out of the harvest season, leaving farming families desperate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: The Ravens Looked to Bounce Back. Then Derrick Henry Showed Up.
description: Titans running back Derrick Henry’s 29-yard touchdown run sealed a contentious overtime win over the Ravens, who have now lost three of their last four games.
content: When two teams scuffle on the field before the game even starts and both head coaches appear to still be at odds after the final whistle, it is pretty clear the contest was something more than just another regular-season N.F.L. game. Indeed, when the Tennessee Titans defeated the Baltimore Ravens, 30-24, in overtime Sunday, the outcome was a weighty, emotional lift for the struggling Titans and their sledgehammer running back, Derrick Henry, who delivered the final gut punch to the reeling Ravens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $450,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Senator Kelly Loeffler of Georgia is in isolation after testing positive for the virus.
description: Senator Kelly Loeffler of Georgia, a Republican who is campaigning in a high-stakes runoff election that could determine control of the Senate, is isolating after testing positive for the coronavirus.
content: Senator Kelly Loeffler of Georgia, a Republican who is campaigning in a high-stakes runoff election that could determine control of the Senate, is isolating after testing positive for the coronavirus on Friday evening and then receiving an inconclusive result on Saturday, a campaign spokesman said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: This Is Getting Awkward
description: The Trump administration is drawing down pandemic aid, but the economy needs all the help it can get.
content: Welcome to the weirdest Thanksgiving week ever. Whether you’re staying home — an excellent choice — or taking your chances by traveling, be safe, and keep your gathering small. (Remember, that means more pie for you.) — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Machine-made molecules fight the coronavirus in lab animals.
description: A team of researchers at the University of Washington has designed and built from scratch a molecule that, when pitted against the coronavirus in the lab, can attack and sequester it at least as well as an antibody does.
content: A team of researchers at the University of Washington has designed and built from scratch a molecule that, when pitted against the coronavirus in the lab, can attack and sequester it at least as well as an antibody does.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Along Russia’s ‘Road of Bones,’ Relics of Suffering and Despair
description: The Kolyma Highway in the Russian Far East once delivered tens of thousands of prisoners to the work camps of Stalin’s gulag. The ruins of that cruel era are still visible today.
content: The prisoners, hacking their way through insect-infested summer swamps and winter ice fields, brought the road, and the road then brought yet more prisoners, delivering a torrent of slave labor to the gold mines and prison camps of Kolyma, the most frigid and deadly outpost of Stalin’s gulag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: 2 Sonic Drive-In Workers Die in Nebraska Shooting
description: Two other employees were injured in the shooting on Saturday night. A man was arrested, but a motive for the episode was unclear.
content: Two employees of a Sonic Drive-In were killed and two others were injured in a shooting on Saturday night in Nebraska, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Dickerson and Lynsey Addario
title: Undocumented and Pregnant: Why Women Are Afraid to Get Prenatal Care
description: Undocumented women are risking their health by postponing prenatal care and giving birth at home in response to the Trump administration’s immigration enforcement policies.
content: EDINBURG, Texas — Britani first learned there was something wrong with her pregnancy late one night in July 2019 when she started bleeding and rushed to an emergency room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: Settle In for the Season With These Films
description: As the cold weather descends, warm your heart with a sports movie or get your blood pumping with suspenseful thrillers.
content: We’ve reached that time of year when the small screen is filled with Christmas movies, populated by happy folks in coats and scarves, frolicking in the snow. This will not be a list of those kinds of films. This collection is more for all of you who love the chilly weather, but who can’t stand “Jingle Bell Rock.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Emily Cochrane
title: Biden Team, Pushing Quick Stimulus Deal, Prepares for Renewed Recession
description: Economists warn that lawmakers must pass aid now, as a renewed coronavirus surge chills consumer spending and business activity.
content: WASHINGTON — Advisers to President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. are planning for the increasing likelihood that the United States economy is headed for a “double-dip” recession early next year. They are pushing for Democratic leaders in Congress to reach a quick stimulus deal with Senate Republicans, even if it falls short of the larger package Democrats have been seeking, according to people familiar with the discussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio and Hannah Wise
title: Coronavirus Upends Thanksgiving for Many, While Others Ignore Warnings
description: Public health officials are advising against the very rituals many families cherish: out-of-state travel and large, indoor gatherings.
content: Ginger Floerchinger-Franks typically invites 10 people to her home in Boise, Idaho, for Thanksgiving dinner and cooks the entire meal herself, including her specialty, pumpkin soup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Oxford’s 2020 Word of the Year? It’s Too Hard to Isolate
description: Instead of crowning a single word as the winner, Oxford Languages looks at the pandemic’s swift and widespread impact on the English language.
content: Oxford Languages’s annual Word of the Year is usually a tribute to the protean creativity of English and the reality of constant linguistic change, throwing a spotlight on zeitgeisty neologisms like “selfie,” “vape” and “unfriend.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein and Jesse McKinley
title: New York City Hit a 3% Positive Test Rate. Or Did It?
description: The city and state use different approaches for calculations. That has led to confusion and has a big impact on which restrictions are adopted.
content: Three percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Jake Scott, Super Bowl M.V.P. for the Dolphins, Dies at 75
description: A fearless defender, he had 35 interceptions in six seasons in Miami and was named to 5 consecutive Pro Bowls in the 1970s.
content: Jake Scott, the free-spirited, hard-nosed free safety who was a cornerstone of the Miami Dolphins dynasty in the 1970s and the Most Valuable Player in Super Bowl VII, which capped the league’s only undefeated season, died on Nov. 19. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: John Belushi in Focus: What a New Film Gets Right and What It Misses
description: After Bob Woodward’s “Wired” focused too much on the comic’s death, this documentary looks fondly at the star’s life. But his comic genius deserves more.
content: In his brief six years on the national stage, no comic was more popular than John Belushi. At the height of his fame, in the late 1970s, he eclipsed even Steve Martin and Robin Williams by starring in the top-rated new phenomenon, “Saturday Night Live” and what was then the highest grossing film comedy ever, “Animal House,” while his band, the Blues Brothers, had the country’s No. 1 album, “Briefcase Full of Blues.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Even Harry Styles in Jorts Can’t Save Gucci’s Mini-Series
description: Neither could Billie Eilish. Or Gus Van Sant. “Ouverture” was a stab at an art house fashion film that doesn’t quite come off. But Guccifest was a different story.
content: A few months ago, back when most live fashion shows got canceled because of the coronavirus pandemic and digital shows took their place, I had a moment of hope. I thought that maybe fashion brands would seize the moment to do something new.
source.name: The New York Times

title: South Dakota and New Mexico offer a snapshot of the alternate realities in the U.S. pandemic.
description: Known coronavirus cases in the United States have now surpassed 12 million, and the daily routines of a vast number of Americans are now shaped by their ZIP codes and governors and beliefs about the virus. Do they wear masks? Go to school in person or online? Eat out? Get exposed to the virus?
content: Known coronavirus cases in the United States have now surpassed 12 million, and the daily routines of a vast number of Americans are now shaped by their ZIP codes and governors and beliefs about the virus. Do they wear masks? Go to school in person or online? Eat out? Get exposed to the virus?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Judith Levitt
title: Thanksgiving, Coronavirus, Presidential Transition: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The E.U. Puts Its Foot Down on the Rule of Law
description: While the leaders of Hungary and Poland resist.
content: After years of passively watching nationalist governments in Hungary and Poland undermine democratic rule, the European Union finally drew the line this year and declared that disbursements from the E.U. budget and a special coronavirus relief fund would be contingent on each member’s adherence to the rule of law. Hungary and Poland have shamelessly retaliated by threatening to veto the Union’s next seven-year budget, emergency funds and all, unless the condition is scrapped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: A Brazilian Writer Saw a Tweet as Tame Satire. Then Came the Lawsuits.
description: The writer J.P. Cuenca calls it “Kafka in the tropics.” Evangelical pastors have filed at least 130 suits against him over a tweet, part of an increasingly common strategy against critics.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — The acerbic tweet came naturally to the Brazilian novelist and journalist J.P. Cuenca, who was several months into a quarantine doom-scrolling routine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: English Gyms Offer a New Workout: Civil Disobedience
description: Despite police raids and the threat of heavy fines, some health clubs have stayed open in an act of defiance against a coronavirus lockdown.
content: LONDON — The technique is deft and the maneuver swift as the instructor first levers his pupil onto one side, then pivots to leave him prostrate and immobilized on the dark blue mat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Black Narcissus’ Review: Nuns, Mountains, High Passion
description: An FX mini-series revisits a story of sexual repression in the Himalayas and includes a final TV performance by Diana Rigg.
content: The title “Black Narcissus” has the sound of a hothouse flower — a dark bloom luring you to an uncertain fate — and the story, as set out by Rumer Godden in her 1939 novel, is indeed exotic, in both the traditional and the pejorative modern senses. Early in the 20th century, five British nuns are sent into the Himalayas to establish a school, hospital and convent in a decrepit mansion perched on a cliff. Exposure to the dramatic landscape and to the down-to-earth locals unhinges them, in different ways and to various degrees, and the project ends in tragedy. If “Heart of Darkness” had a much more genteel cousin, it would be “Black Narcissus.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: It’s the run-up to Thanksgiving, and time to start preparing for the meal, even if it’s a bit smaller this year.
content: Good morning. This is a big day for Thanksgiving preparations even if all you’re going to be doing is making these turkey cutlets Marsala (above) that I learned to cook while reading and writing about Elizabeth David. (They’re good with vegetable risotto and roasted brussels sprouts.) You’ve got to secure the ingredients, after all, and you really ought to make a plan for what the table’s going to look like on Thursday, how you want the meal to go, smaller than usual, in this most curious year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jodi Levine
title: Scatter Paper Leaves to Dress Up Your Table
description: With a little paint and accordion folding, your newspaper can become décor for your Thanksgiving table.
content: This Thanksgiving, whether you’re hosting guests or sharing a meal via Zoom, it’s worth the effort to dress up your table to make the day feel different, special even. Fall leaves are an obvious and lovely decorative element but if yours have withered or blown away, create a few leaves of your own from accordion-folded paper.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Dolly: Country Music Legend, Songwriter, Pandemic Hero
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 22, 2020.
content: “Shakespeare may have written King Lear during the plague, but Dolly Parton funded a Covid vaccine, dropped a Christmas album and a Christmas special.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Cases are climbing quickly in Japan and South Korea.
content: The coronavirus pandemic is taking a bad turn in parts of Asia. Cases are climbing quickly in Japan and South Korea, which had long managed to avoid the worst. And because Hong Kong is grappling with a spike, a plan for a travel bubble between Hong Kong and Singapore has been put on hold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Parker
title: Abandon Your Thanksgiving Script
description: This year, we have a chance to build a different kind of holiday.
content: This is the year for an improv Thanksgiving.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Was on My Sunset Walk When I Came Upon a Gorgeous Ballerina’
description: A dancer at the water’s edge, seeing a scary movie and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Michael Levenson
title: Fatal Shooting of 2 Black Teenagers by Florida Deputy Is Under Investigation
description: Relatives are demanding answers about the shooting deaths of Angelo Crooms, 16, and Sincere Pierce, 18, by a sheriff’s deputy in Cocoa, Fla.
content: The authorities are investigating the fatal shooting by a Florida sheriff’s deputy of two Black teenagers who were in a moving car during an encounter with law enforcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman
title: How Trump Hopes to Use Party Machinery to Retain Control of the G.O.P.
description: Ronna McDaniel, a close ally of President Trump, wants to remain head of the Republican National Committee, worrying party members who believe the president will try to use the group to keep control of the G.O.P.
content: As President Trump brazenly seeks to delay the certification of the election in hopes of overturning his defeat, he is also mounting a less high-profile but similarly audacious bid to keep control of the Republican National Committee even after he leaves office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Judge Dismisses Trump Lawsuit Seeking to Delay Certification in Pennsylvania
description: In a scathing order, a federal judge rejected the Trump campaign’s claim of widespread improprieties with mail-in ballots, removing a major legal hurdle to certifying Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory there.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Getting Ready for a Pandemic Thanksgiving
description: Readers offer cautions for those determined to celebrate in the usual way.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: For Better Data on Hate Crimes
description: The Anti-Defamation League supports legislation that would “enhance the accuracy” of F.B.I. statistics. Also: Exit Trump.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
